title.narrative: HPN - Afya Uzazi: FP/RMNCAH Nakuru and Baringo

description.narrative: (Kenya): .The Afya Uzazi project in Baringo and Nakuru counties by unlocking the potential of healthy, educated, and productive populations is driving inclusive and sustainable development to advance Kenya's journey to self-reliance. USAID investments strengthen health systems and build local capacity for family planning, reproductive, maternal, newborn, child, and adolescent health, nutrition, water, sanitation, and hygiene. Activities focus on building commitment and capacity at community, facility, sub-county, and county levels to respond to health needs of citizens, particularly poor and vulnerable groups. This activity builds the capacity of county and sub-county health managers on management, accountability, and governance to enhance ownership and reduce donor dependency. Counties are sensitized on domestic resource mobilization approaches to secure health funds. To support universal health coverage, the number of National Health Insurance Fund accredited facilities will be increased, and enrollment expanded to rural populations. This activity enhances the leadership role of the sub-county in health systems for integrated supply chain, enhancing the quality of the health information system, mentorship, and supportive supervision of health workers, and service quality improvement. Social behavior change through local organizations and community health volunteers prioritizes healthy timing and spacing of births, postnatal care for newborns, and broad social norm changes to prevent gender-based violence. Through a multi-sectoral approach, Afya Uzazi connects local health issues to larger development challenges through integrated population, health, and development activities. Strengthening county and local institutions' capacity ensures sustainable development and this activity protects America's values and leadership in disease prevention as indicated in Goal three of the State Department and USAID Joint Strategic Plan... .
